message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results suggest a possible diverticular abscess or perforation, which can be confirmed with a CT scan of the abdomen with contrast. Abdominal ultrasound and abdominal x-ray may not provide enough detail, and flexible sigmoidoscopy would not be appropriate for evaluating the entire colon.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination indicate a possible diagnosis of diverticulitis. CT scan is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity of the condition. Abdominal ultrasound may not provide enough detail and sensitivity to identify diverticulitis. Flexible sigmoidoscopy and abdominal x-ray are not recommended for the initial evaluation of suspected diverticulitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the symptoms, laboratory values and physical exam findings, the most likely diagnosis is diverticulitis, which can be confirmed with a CT scan of the abdomen with contrast. Abdominal ultrasound and flexible sigmoidoscopy may not provide adequate visualization of the affected area, and an abdominal x-ray may not show the extent of inflammation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute diverticulitis, which is best confirmed with a CT scan of the abdomen with contrast. Abdominal ultrasound may not provide enough detail and flexible sigmoidoscopy and abdominal x-ray are not appropriate for confirming the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible diagnosis of diverticulitis, and CT scan of the abdomen with contrast is the most appropriate imaging study to confirm the diagnosis. Abdominal ultrasound may miss the diagnosis, flexible sigmoidoscopy is not indicated in the acute setting, and abdominal x-ray is unlikely to show anything useful.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient may have diverticulitis, which is a common cause of lower abdominal pain. A CT scan with contrast is the most appropriate test for confirming a diagnosis of diverticulitis, as it can help identify the inflamed diverticula and any associated complications such as abscesses or perforations. Abdominal ultrasound, flexible sigmoidoscopy, and abdominal x-ray are less sensitive and specific for the diagnosis of diverticulitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest diverticulitis. To confirm the diagnosis, a CT scan of the abdomen with contrast is most appropriate as it can visualize the presence of inflamed diverticula and any associated abscesses or complications. Abdominal ultrasound and abdominal x-ray are less sensitive and may not provide a definitive diagnosis. Flexible sigmoidoscopy is contraindicated in the acute phase due to the risk of perforation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings suggest diverticulitis. CT scan of the abdomen with contrast is the most appropriate imaging study to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of the disease. Abdominal ultrasound can also be useful but is less sensitive. Flexible sigmoidoscopy and abdominal x-ray are not the preferred imaging modalities for the diagnosis of diverticulitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms that suggest acute diverticulitis, such as left lower quadrant tenderness and a tender mass on digital rectal examination. CT scan of the abdomen with contrast is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis of acute diverticulitis and to assess the extent and severity of the disease. Abdominal ultrasound may be useful to evaluate for other causes of abdominal pain, such as cholecystitis, but is not as sensitive as CT scan for diagnosing diverticulitis. Flexible sigmoidoscopy and abdominal x-ray have limited utility in the diagnosis of diverticulitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of diverticulitis, which includes lower abdominal pain, fever, vomiting, and altered bowel movements. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count increase, which is often seen in diverticulitis. Of the options provided, CT scan of the abdomen with contrast is the most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis as it can identify inflammation, abscesses, and perforations in the colon. Abdominal ultrasound and x-ray can help with initial assessment, but may not be sufficient for diagnosis confirmation. Flexible sigmoidoscopy may also not be suitable for this purpose as it only assesses the distal colon.
